column1: Qadian () is a town and a municipal council in Gurdaspur District
column3: situated 18 kilometres (11 mi) north-east of Batala city in the state of Punjab

column1: Qadian is the birthplace of Mirza Ghulam Ahmad
column2: the founder of the Ahmadiyya  movement. It remained the centre of the Ahmadiyya movement until the Partition of India in 1947.

column1: Qadian was established in 1530 by Mirza Hadi Baig
column2: a religious scholar dedicated to Islam and the first Qazi in the area. Mirza Hadi Baig was from a royal household of Mirza of the Mughal Empire. He migrated from Samarkand and settled in Punjab where he was granted a vast tract of land comprising 80 villages by the emperor Babur. Because of his religious beliefs
column3: he named the center of the 80 villages Islam Pur Qazi and governed from there. Over time
column4: the name of the town changed to Qazi Maji
column6: and eventually it became known as 'Qadian'.
